intro: Paepalanthus widgrenianus, commonly known as the Widgren's puya, is a flowering plant native to the high Andes of South America. It belongs to the Bromeliaceae family and is characterized by its rosette-forming leaves that collect water, creating a small pool that supports aquatic life. The plant produces striking inflorescences with showy, tubular flowers that attract pollinators such as hummingbirds and bees. It thrives in cool, humid environments at high altitudes, often in rocky or sandy soils. Due to its unique adaptations and ecological significance, it is a subject of interest in botanical research and conservation efforts.
